prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ID141_[NII]122
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [NII] 122 micron line in HATLAS J142413.9+022304 (ID141).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We conservatively assume a line luminosity ratio [NII]122/[CII]=0.06. We estimate the line flux based on the published [CII] detection. High redshift fine structure lines are typically broad (~several hundred km/s) so we choose an intrinsic spectral resolution of 977 kHz and bin on the fly by a factor of 16 to keep data rates low. From (Cox et al. 2011) we have a very good estimate of the continuum flux density, but in all our cases, the fine structure lines are strong compared to the continuum and we are in no danger of pushing against dynamic range limits.
Assuming the minimum line luminosity, we will achieve a S/N of 5 over a spectral range equivalent to the FWHM of the detected [CII] line.
We have set the three additional basebands to cover the maximum spectral range to acquire strong continuum detections. We also cover the frequency of CO (22-21). We do not intend to study this line, but since it can be strong in intense X-ray dissociated regions, we have positioned our basebands to allow the opportunity for serendipitous science.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ID141_[OI]146
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [OI] 146 micron line in HATLAS J142413.9+022304 (ID141).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our justification follows the same logic as the [NII] 122 micron line in this source.
We conservatively assume a line luminosity ratio [OI]146/[CII]=0.037. Our additional basebands cover the maximum spectral range to acquire strong continuum and also cover the frequency of CO (18-17).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ID141_[NII]205
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [NII] 205 micron line in HATLAS J142413.9+022304 (ID141).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our justification follows the same logic as the [NII] 122 micron line in this source.
We conservatively assume a line luminosity ratio [NII]205/[CII]=0.04. Our additional basebands cover the maximum spectral range to acquire strong continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: TNJ0924_[NII]122
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [NII] 122 micron line in TN J0924-221

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our justification follows the same logic as the [NII] 122 micron line in ID 141.
We estimate the [CII] line luminosity from the detected CO (1-0) line (Klamer et al. 2005). We assume a line luminosity ratio [CII]/CO(1-0)=2600 which is a conservative estimate for star forming galaxies which this appears to be. To find the [NII] 122 line luminosity from [CII] we continue to assume [NII]122/[CII]=0.06.
Our additional basebands cover the maximum spectral range to acquire strong continuum and also cover the frequency of CO (22-21)
We estimate the FIR luminosity as L_FIR/L_CO=1e6, arriving at L_FIR~4e12 Lsun. At z=5.2, the observed flux density near the peak of the FIR dust continuum for a source of this luminosity will be ~5mJy. Although the approximation is rough, if we are off by even an order of magnitude we will still easily detect the continuum and not be in danger of broaching dynamic range limits.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: TNJ0924_[OI]146
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [OI] 146 micron line in TN J0924-221

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our justification follows the same logic as the [NII] 122 micron line in ID 141.
We estimate the [CII] line luminosity from the detected CO (1-0) line (Klamer et al. 2005). We assume a line luminosity ratio [CII]/CO(1-0)=2600 which is a conservative estimate for star forming galaxies which this appears to be. To find [OI] line luminosities from [CII] we continue to assume [OI]146/[CII]=0.037.
Our additional basebands cover the maximum spectral range to acquire strong continuum and also cover the frequency of CO (18-17)

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: TNJ0924_[CII]158
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [CII] 158 micron line in TN J0924-221

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our justification follows the same logic as the [NII] 122 micron line in ID 141.
We estimate the [CII] line luminosity from the detected CO (1-0) line (Klamer et al. 2005). We assume a line luminosity ratio [CII]/CO(1-0)=2600 which is a conservative estimate for star forming galaxies which this appears to be.
Our additional basebands cover the maximum spectral range to acquire strong continuum and also cover the frequency of CO (16-15)

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: TNJ0924_[NII]205
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [NII] 205 micron line in TN J0924-221

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our justification follows the same logic as the [NII] 122 micron line in ID 141.
We estimate the [CII] line luminosity from the detected CO (1-0) line (Klamer et al. 2005). We assume a line luminosity ratio [CII]/CO(1-0)=2600 which is a conservative estimate for star forming galaxies which this appears to be. To estimate the [NII] 205 line luminosity from [CII] we continue to assume [NII]205/[CII]=0.04.
Our additional basebands cover the maximum spectral range to acquire strong continuum and also cover the frequency of CO (12-11)

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: BR1202_[NII]122
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [NII] 122 micron line in BR 1202 N

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our justification follows the same logic as the [NII] 122 micron line in ID 141. We continue to assume [NII]122/[CII]=0.06.
We take the continuum underneath the [CII] line (Wagg et al. 2012) as our estimate.
We also note that the nearby QSO BR 1202 S is less than 4" away and their systemic velocities are only 23 km/s different. Although our science does not depend on it, it is very likely we will additionally observe BR 1202 S. Although the [CII] line flux in BR 1202 is smaller (9.6 Jy km/s), its FWHM is smaller as well (328 km/s). Based on our requested integration time for BR1202 N, and accounting for a slight decrease in sensitivity 4" away from beam center, we should achieve a S/N of 4.5 on BR 1202 S.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: BR1202_[OI]146
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [NII] 122 micron line in BR 1202 N

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our justification follows the same logic as the [NII] 122 micron line in this source.
We continue to assume [OI]146/[CII]=0.037. Our basebands have been arranged to provide continuum sensitivity and cover the CO (18-17) frequency.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: BR1202_[NII]205
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [NII] 122 micron line in BR 1202 N

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our justification follows the same logic as the [NII] 122 micron line in this source.
We continue to assume [NII]205/[CII]=0.04. Our basebands have been arranged to provide continuum sensitivity and cover the CO (12-11) frequency.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: LESSJ0332_[NII]122
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the [NII] 122 micron line in LESS J0332

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our justification follows the same logic as the [NII] 122 micron line in ID 141. We continue to assume [NII]122/[CII]=0.06.
Nagao et al. 2012 find a continuum of 3.5 mJy at 210 microns. Multiplying by 2.5 to estimate the peak of the FIR dust peak we estimate our continuum as ~10 mJy.
Our bandpasses are selected to cover the freequency of CO 22-21

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: LESSJ0332_[OI]145
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the OI 146 micron line in LESS J0332

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our justification follows the same logic as the [NII] 122 micron line in ID 141. We continue to assume [NII]122/[CII]=0.06.
Our bandpasses are selected to cover the freequency of CO 22-21

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: With a modest ALMA survey of the four bright far-IR fine-structure lines ([NII] 122 and 205 micron, [OI] 146 micron, and [CII] 158 micron) we will characterize the gas in ionized and photo dissociated regions in a set of four star forming galaxies at z>4. We will establish the density of the ionized and photo-dissociated gas regions, characterize the intensity of the far-UV radiation, and constrain the numbers of Lyman continuum photons. This will provide new insight into the first chapters of galaxy evolution by determining star formation rates, the spatial extent of star formation, and nitrogen to carbon abundance ratios which will give the first unambiguous indications of metallicity in galactic ionized regions within ~1.5 Gyr of the birth of the Universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals:
2013.1.00400.S Carl Ferkinhoff 'The first survey of [OIII] and [NII] at high-z: unique insights into early galaxies' Will examine [OIII] and [NII] 122 micron line at high redshift to characterize the highly ionized medium. This complements our project by characterizing photon regions with energies above 29.6 eV (the maximum our lines probe.) Among other science goals, it will help characterize the stellar mass function in high z galaxies.
2013.1.01005.S Gordon Stacey 'ALMA [NII]/[CII] Investigations at z~3: Tracking Modes of Star Formation at its Historic Peak' This proposal will study similar constituents of the ISM as our proposal, but at lower redshifts, providing a transition between our work in the epoch of peak star formation efficiency (z~1-2), and in the early Universe during the first stages of galaxy formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
